title: E field of distribution - E from ring at pts X Y Z

content.question: A conducting ring of radius <math alttext="uppercase R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> has a net charge <math alttext="uppercase Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Q</mi></math> uniformly distributed around its circumference. Points <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>, <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>, and <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></math> lie along the ringâ€™s central axis at the locations indicated in the figure. Which of the following correctly ranks the magnitude <math alttext="E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>E</mi></math> of the electric field at points <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>, <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>, and <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Z</mi></math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="E sub X, is greater than E sub Y, which is greater than E sub Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>Z</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="E sub Y equals E sub Z, which is greater than E sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>Z</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="E sub Y, is greater than E sub Z, which is greater than E sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>Z</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="E sub Z, is greater than E sub Y, which is greater than E sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>Z</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="E sub Y, is greater than E sub Z, which is greater than E sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>Z</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>

unit.text: 8: Electric Charges, Fields, and Gauss's Law

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
